body:
Could it be that this broke something as well? we get a lot of these errors now:

`error[E0658]:  use of unstable library feature 'try_from' (see issue #33417)`

https://travis-ci.org/apache/thrift/jobs/519745808

It was supposed to be stable in 1.33, but didn't make it till 1.34
(11/04/2019). Will check travis runs and settings though.
On Sat, Apr 13, 2019, 5:02 PM Jens Geyer <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Could it be that this broke something as well? we get a lot of these
> errors now:
>
> error[E0658]: use of unstable library feature 'try_from' (see issue #33417)
>
> https://travis-ci.org/apache/thrift/jobs/519745808
>
> —

> <https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1752#issuecomment-482896608>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABaFFDPDKwgT6nun3WuEygP86-JWGcYSks5vgmH7gaJpZM4bmKL8>
> .
>
@allengeorge Should I open up a PR to make https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/build/docker/ubuntu-bionic/Dockerfile#L259 just use rustup and stable? Same for xenial.

Yes please. And, thank you.

I used to have the images download a pinned stable, but at some point it was changed to the distribution-packaged rust.

The minimum Rust version is going to have to change, and he CHANGES.md file is going to have to list this as a breaking change (as well as the Rust README).


________________________________

Subject: Re: [apache/thrift] THRIFT-4536: TryFrom stable (#1752)


@allengeorge<https://github.com/allengeorge> Should I open up a PR to make https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/build/docker/ubuntu-bionic/Dockerfile#L259 just use rustup and stable? Same for xenial.

—

@cchalmers : Thanks! I gave it a try ...
@allengeorge Do you know of any other build scripts that need rust stable?

Seems like this also broke the windows build (we have Haskell on Windows in our CI) in another build (the Rust 1.34 PR)):

https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/thrift/builds/23864846

> Seems like this also broke the windows build (we have Haskell on Windows in our CI) in another build

I don't see the connection between the two? What do I overlook?
At least this seems to solve *one* issue. Any objections against merging this? Jim?
LGTM, not tested
Thanks, now lets tackle the Rust issue.
@dbcfd could you force-push this again please?

@Jens-G simple force didn't work, deleted/pushed and reopened.

Appveyor failed with 
```
> jdk8 v8.0.201 [Approved]
jdk8 package files install completed. Performing other installation steps.

merged, thanks
Any idea why tests are failing?
I saw some fixes go in last week for some of the issues like the Haskell issue, so first try rebasing your pull request and let's see what happens.
This is a generic issue across many of the language implementations.
Seeing a lot of different build failures... I'll try to work on it.

Ma I ask you to also file a JIRA ticket for this?
http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute

It would be ideal to have a test that ensures this does not break in the future.
Otherwise PR looks good.  If the builds fail it's probably CI and not your code.  I have some work to do to stabilize CI.

> It would be ideal to have a test that ensures this does not break in the future.

I completely agree! Unfortunately I'm way too busy with other work to add a test right now. As there were no tests for this class anyway, it figured it would be best to at least fix the bug for now.

I only mention this because I wasn't clear from your comment whether you were waiting on me for that before accepting the pull request. Cheers!
@jeking3 Hm, looks like the problem in build itself, not in my changes?
I agree, but we like to get clean builds before we merge stuff, so we need to wait for the golang issue to be resolved by @dcelasun and then we'll ask folks to rebase things.
I see, thanks for response.
Bravo, you have waited 2+ years and then due to your inactivity you closed issue ... Excellent approach

@patrikkempec I can't speak to the behavior of the committer team before I got involved, but the author abandoned the work.  

You can re-open it after rebasing on the current master if you would like it to be reconsidered.

Looks like we need a similar fix to npm jsdoc being too new for xenial... ignore the xenial build result.  Working on it.

jsdoc 3.6 only supports node 8.5 or later.  We support node 4.x, but it looks like our own files are all correct, which means something else is likely pulling in jsdoc 3.6 somehow, but I'll need to look at it more.

Our js deps were incorrectly using carat and should have been tilde; I'm fixing.

Looks like something got merged before it passed tests.
```
make[4]: Entering directory '/thrift/src/lib/netstd'

cc: @Jens-G

> Looks like something got merged before it passed tests.

Yes, which is why I tested it on a branch without Jens' commits and Travis passed. See [here](https://travis-ci.org/dcelasun/thrift/jobs/530827556) and [here](https://travis-ci.org/dcelasun/thrift/jobs/530827557).

So I'm gonna go ahead and merge this.
The remaining build failures are in netstd.  cc: @Jens-G
erl tests passed despite the CI issues
Closing based on comments.
Closing based on comments.
@jeking3 Rebased, looks good

I agree with your fix, I was just suggesting there could be more collisions now that there are only two numeric inputs which would lead to incorrect behavior when using the value as a key in a container.  I was not suggesting your changes were bad; sorry if that was the impression.  I will rebase your PR after I add a unit test and get it building again, so no further action is needed on your side.

>  I was not suggesting your changes were bad; sorry if that was the impression.

I understood that, no worries. I was just saying that "fixing something completely broken" and "twiddling with a conjectured inefficiency that we don't even know exists" are two separate things and should be done in two different tickets, in my opinion.

Have a great day!
Yeah, I tend to combine things for efficiency when I am in a general area of code.  I get way more done that way.  Thanks.

I rebased this on master. 

One of the tests failed, though I'm not sure I see why.
So we made these changes to enums and the tutorial was broken, and none of the builds caught that?  @allengeorge it sounds like the build is missing something.

I agree with you in that this is an improvement.  My comments were really just about the whole offline queue in general, and how it really isn't guaranteeing anything.  I'm not sure something like that belongs in the thrift transport implementation at all.  Given clients are asynchronous already, they should implement their own request timeouts and re-submit requests, and design their systems to have idempotent requests.
[nods] Will take a look. I really thought I did, and fixed it. I'm super surprised it didn't break.

I can merge this as-is, but I'm thinking it might be better to fix the original error (we shouldn't have a pointer to a slice) even if it's a BC break (we just need to [mention it](https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/c035eca3c672511779440bd0779ce5bc93d5c327/CHANGES.md#breaking-changes)). It's better for maintainability and will be less surprising for anyone who runs into it.

Thoughts?
@jeking3 I rebase it to latest master

I definitely agree we shouldn’t have a pointer to a slice (or a pointer to a map). Do you think it will be as simple as never returning true from is_pointer for those types? I can try but probably not until next week.

If we’re making breaking changes anyways would it make more sense to use a map type as a set? E.g `map[string]struct{}` for a set of strings? That’s a pretty common way to represent sets in Go.

> On May 16, 2019, at 23:23, Duru Can Celasun <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> I can merge this as-is, but I'm thinking it might be better to fix the original error (we shouldn't have a pointer to a slice) even if it's a BC break (we just need to mention it). It's better for maintainability and will be less surprising for anyone who runs into it.
> 
> Thoughts?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

> Do you think it will be as simple as never returning true from is_pointer for those types?

Yes, I think that should be enough.

> I can try but probably not until next week.

No rush.

> If we’re making breaking changes anyways would it make more sense to use a map type as a set? E.g `map[string]struct{}` for a set of strings? That’s a pretty common way to represent sets in Go.

Actually, it was originally like that but [I changed it](https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/43fb34df2871b69c2f34dc3bb353e65cbc9f8692) to slices because map keys in Go must be [comparable](https://golang.org/ref/spec#Comparison_operators) and there are lots of valid Thrift sets where the values are not valid Go map keys. Using a slice and enforcing uniqueness via `reflect.DeepEqual` provides a better user experience.
Good to know. Thanks for the context!
Looks okay to me.  Too bad we don't have any SASL represented in the cross test suite.

I've gotten started on this but it is more complex than I expected. I can see the light at the end of the tunnel though.

It looks like the `is_pointer_field` method gets also used in different parts of the code to indicate whether a value is optional, and also whether a value needs a `*` or `&` in front of it. I'm going to split out a new `need_pointer_redirect` method to indicate whether the value needs a `*` or `&` in front of it. I'll also probably split out an `is_optional_field` method for convenience.

|                       | map | opt map | slice | opt slice | string | opt string | int/float/bool | opt int/float/bool | struct | opt struct |
|-----------------------|-----|---------|-------|-----------|--------|------------|-----------|---------------|--------|------------|
| is_pointer_field      | Y   | Y       | Y     | Y         | N      | Y          | N         | Y             | N      | Y          |
| need_pointer_redirect | N   | N       | N     | N         | N      | Y          | N         | Y             | N      | Y          |
| is_optional_field     | N   | Y       | N     | Y         | N      | Y          | N         | Y             | N      | Y          |

I generally welcome that patch, I had in on my todo as well. But I am against the others unrelated stuff. If you think we need that please file another ticket for it and let's discuss these changes separtely. If you could do that, I will commit it (unless I find something else), but **in the current form it is a clear -1 from me**.
@jeking3 The ruby thing is clearly unrelated, but what really sucks is the mingw update error at AppVeyor. Is there anything I can do about that? Thoughts?
You're right. Sometimes old habits come back and haunt me. Let me clear out the non-topic specific changes.

Hi @jeking3 
I rebased on master
@dcelasun tagging you because you expressed interest in the [JIRA ticket](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-4612) :)
The failures on travis are due to transient network failures (to pull build dependencies). The corresponding builds are passing on https://travis-ci.com/fishy/thrift/builds/115286920

This rabbit hole keeps getting deeper. I'm trying to get a handle on all the special cases with a lookup table that includes optional/required, default values, cpp.ref, types, and how all those factors affect the generated code. It's very complex! This sheet is an attempt at highlighting how things should work when I make the change to not pointers to map/slice types (since they're always pointers).

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Q90gi8zylkf1XTDJiY5ViMCjkTz69PYuk0uOjcI1Yc8/edit?usp=sharing

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/218876/59394483-a6eee280-8d34-11e9-8d0a-03b7a492811a.png)

I've also found [THRIFT-2451](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2451) and [THRIFT-2429](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2429) to be helpful reading to get more historical context.

I have a few questions / proposals:
- Can we drop `cpp.ref` support? It doesn't seem to [do anything](https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/compiler/cpp/src/thrift/generate/t_go_generator.cc#L375) except affect whether native (int/string/bool/double) types are pointers or not. In the case of map/slice it currently also forces those to be pointers pointer types when they don't have a default value, but since maps and slices are already pointers, I don't think this has any practical effect.
- @dcelasun what do you think about merging this change first to fix compilation without making an API-incompatible change. Happy to keep working on the bigger change to not use pointers to maps and slices.

> Can we drop cpp.ref support?

I think so, yes. @jeking3 any thoughts?

> what do you think about merging this change first to fix compilation without making an API-incompatible change?

Sounds reasonable, given how the scope keeps growing. I'll merge it later today.
Merged. @johnboiles please open a new PR for the rest. Even if it's not ready, I could provide feedback.

Thanks for the PR! From a quick look, this seems really good. Nice catch with the framed transport bug as well.

I'll probably have some time next week to do a proper review.
Thanks @dcelasun will do

Just found another case to handle here. I should also detect collisions with the golang packages that get [imported](https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/compiler/cpp/src/thrift/generate/t_go_generator.cc#L875) like `bytes` `context` `reflect`
For stdlib collisions like `context` etc, it would be great if the import list was a vector instead of a hardcoded string so we could reuse it everywhere.
I cringe a bit at the terminology used above. We have protocols, layered and endpoint transports. We don't have "sub-protocols" or "transforms"
What's blocking this?

@Jens-G "transforms" are defined in header format: https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/doc/specs/HeaderFormat.md

I used the term "subprotocol" to distinguish from "protocol" in THeaderProtocol. I'm open to suggestions.

Not sure. I took a look at the failed test runs for a few minutes and couldn't find anything that indicated issues with this patch, but it's a wall of text and I'm not familiar enough with the test suite to be able to diagnose what went wrong.
CI complains about ```clear()``` being a protected method?

> CI complains about `clear()` being a protected method?
Yes, it is, I"ll close this PR and re-submit one later. Sorry for the carelessness.

I don't know why AppVeyor build failed. BTW, i'm a beginner. I've just do some researching thrift source(in lua) for my job and i saw this little mistake. So that i want to contribute to this thrift source in lua.

I'm working on the appveyor issue; Lua isn't tested on Appveyor.  Looks like these changes broke most of the Travis CI builds.  You can run the cross tests locally using our docker image to prove out your changes before submitting them for a PR.

I renamed `Subprotocol*` into `Protocol*` based on the feedbacks (and also in comments, use "wrapped protocol" to refer to them instead of "subprotocol"). I didn't rename `Transform*` because that name is in header format spec doc.

The commit message was also updated accordingly.
Did you read what I wrote in the ticket?
@jeking3 ping
I kicked the failing job which had some java-cpp cross test timeouts.
Ping

> Ping
Sorry for the late reply. I've replied a comment in the ticket, and here is a digest:
1. It's fine to reinitialize protocol/transport stack from scratch, but might not close sockets as subsequent requests(maybe another thrift method that works fine) could re-use them. Opening a lot sockets consume a lot resources and could easily lead to Socket Exceptions.
2. If this is an issue, it exist in both client side and server side, my fix is in client side. I need to dive more into source code to see how to fix it in server side, probably Server.Execute() as you suggest.
Any more suggestion is welcome.
I'm going to close this; I don't want it to mistakenly get merged.
@allengeorge any news?

> 
> 
> @allengeorge any news?

It's just a change in the Readme.md file :)
I'll make the Jira ticket and merge this.  We're going to start a release cycle shortly.

Sadly, this actually removed erlang from all our CI builds, since the standard Ubuntu Bionic erlang installation doesn't include rebar3.  I blame myself for not actually checking any of the build logs.  I'm working to fix it.

I made these changes entirely in macOS, so I had to add "Darwin" to "platforms". Should this be committed too?

Here are my notes on how to setup a macOS environment with Homebrew (I am on macOS 10.15) to build and test c_glib:

```
brew install python3 libtool automake bison pkg-config glib openssl
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/bison/bin:$PATH" # add bison to path
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig:$PKG_CONFIG_PATH" # so pkg-config finds libffi for gobject-2.0
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl/lib/pkgconfig:$PKG_CONFIG_PATH"
./bootstrap.sh
./configure \
	--with-c_glib \
	--without-cpp \
	--without-boost \
	--without-libevent \
	--without-qt5 \
	--without-csharp \
	--without-java \
	--without-erlang \
	--without-nodejs \
	--without-nodets \
	--without-lua \
	--without-python \
	--without-py3 \
	--without-perl \
	--without-php \
	--without-php_extension \
	--without-dart \
	--without-ruby \
	--without-haskell \
	--without-go \
	--without-swift \
	--without-rs \
	--without-cl \
	--without-haxe \
	--without-donotcore \
	--without-d \
	--prefix=$(pwd)/output
make -j$(sysctl -n hw.ncpu) cross PYTHON=$(which python3) CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl/include"
```
When fixing documentation issues, add the text `[ci skip]` to the end of your commit message so it does not engage all the builds.  Thanks.

https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-Memory-Allocation.html#g-free

> If mem is NULL it simply returns, so there is no need to check mem against NULL before calling this function.

You can use the thrift docker container to leverage the same build environment the CI system uses to test with, in an environment where most of the languages are installed.  See https://github.com/apache/thrift/tree/master/build/docker
@BELUGABEHR: any news here?
@soroshsabz: any news here?
I would suggest to start with the conflict :-)
@dcelasun I made it use a vector for system imports can you take a look? I’ll squash it together if/when it looks good to you!
Looks good!
Is it possible to add a Delphi runtime to the Travis CI image so we can run the cross test with these changes?
@dcelasun squashed and ready to merge!
Actually hold on merging for a bit. I _may_ have found another edge case

Yep, confirmed. If the package has a service, and that package’s last namespace component conflicts with a previously imported package, it won’t get aliased. Hopefully I can get a chance to fix tomorrow
@dcelasun one more commit to review to fix the issue with the remote package import collisions! Hopefully this is it
LGTM. Tried testing a few different scenarios locally, everything works fine. Thanks for the PR!

@jeking3 Sorry for the delay. I'm trying to fix the rust tutorial build failures right now, and I'll try to fix the rust build specifically so that we use a pinned version of rustc as opposed to whatever's on stable at the time the docker container is built.
